0001.title: Content Addressing on the Decentralized Web
0001.description: Learn how hashing and content addressing enable verifiable data sharing with peers on the decentralized web.
0001.updateMessage: This tutorial, formerly known as Decentralized Data Structures, has been updated to focus exclusively on content addressing, while our new Merkle DAGs tutorial explores content-addressable data structures in greater depth.

resources.title: Merkle DAGs: Structuring Data for the Distributed Web
resources.description: Learn about the benefits of Merkle DAGs, unique content-addressed data structures for the distributed web. (No coding required.)

resources.title: Anatomy of a CID
resources.description: Dive deeper into how CIDs are constructed in IPFS, from multihash and multicodec prefixes to CID versions. (No coding required.)

resources.title: Decentralized Web Primer: The Power of Content-Addressing
resources.description: A beginner-friendly primer on content addressing from Matt Zumwalt.

resources.title: The Next Internet Revolution
resources.description: In this excerpt from his TedX Talk, Juan Benet explains how the InterPlanetary File System (IPFS) uses content addressing to reframe our model for sharing knowledge.

resources.title: Why is Decentralized and Distributed File Storage Critical for a Better Web?
resources.description: Juan Benet, Jesse Clayburgh, and Matt Zumwalt of Protocol Labs explain how advances in distributed data storage and strong alignment of market incentives are combining to create a more secure and efficient web.

resources.title: Instructions for Saving Endangered Data
resources.description: Matt Zumwalt of IPFS explains why data isn't safe on the centralized web and how IPFS can be used to protect it.

resources.title: HTTP is Obsolete. It's Time for the Distributed, Permanent Web.
resources.description: Kyle Drake of Neocities explores the downsides of the Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP).

resources.title: Understanding How IPFS Deals with Files
resources.description: This course from IPFS Camp 2019 offers a deep exploration of how IPFS deals with files, including key concepts like immutability, content addressing, hashing, the anatomy of CIDs, what the heck a Merkle DAG is, and how chunk size affects file imports.

resources.title: IPFS: Mutable File System (MFS)
resources.description: Explore the Mutable File System (MFS), which lets you work with files and directories in IPFS as if you were using a traditional name-based file system. (This tutorial includes JavaScript code challenges.)

resources.title: P2P Data Links with Content Addressing
resources.description: Use the IPFS DAG API to create create verifiable links between dataset with Content Identifiers (CIDs). (This tutorial includes JavaScript code challenges.)

resources.title: The Lifecycle of Data in the DWeb
resources.description: This course from IPFS Camp 2019 explores how users share files on IPFS, from providing to getting to pinning to deleting.

0002.title: P2P Data Links with Content Addressing
0002.description: Store, fetch, and create verifiable links between peer-hosted datasets using the IPFS DAG API and CIDs. Itâ€™s graphs with friends!
0002.updateMessage: Version `0.48` of `js-ipfs` has introduced some changes, most notably by changing `ipfs.dag.get` by moving the `path` into the `options` object. This means that **some code challenge solutions have changed**. We recommend re-visiting this tutorial to learn about the updated methods and complete the revised challenges!

resources.title: Merkle DAGs: Structuring Data for the Distributed Web
resources.description: Learn about the benefits of Merkle DAGs, unique content-addressed data structures for the distributed web. (No coding required.)

resources.title: Blogging on the Decentralized Web
resources.description: Ready for a bigger challenge with the IPFS DAG API? Use CIDs to build and update a complex web of data.

resources.title: Understanding How IPFS Deals with Files
resources.description: This course from IPFS Camp 2019 offers a deep exploration of how IPFS deals with files, including key concepts like immutability, content addressing, hashing, the anatomy of CIDs, what the heck a Merkle DAG is, and how chunk size affects file imports.

resources.title: The Lifecycle of Data in the DWeb
resources.description: Curious about what happens _after_ you've added data to IPFS? This IPFS Camp 2019 course explores how peers discover and share files on the network, from providing to getting to pinning to deleting.

resources.title: IPFS: Regular Files API
resources.description: Ready to deal with more than primitives? Explore the API custom-built for efficient handling of files in IPFS.

0003.title: Blogging on the Decentralized Web
0003.description: Cool content addresses don't change. Create a chain of links from one CID to another with the IPFS DAG API.

resources.title: Merkle DAGs: Structuring Data for the Distributed Web
resources.description: Learn about the benefits of Merkle DAGs, unique content-addressed data structures for the distributed web. (No coding required.)

resources.title: Understanding How IPFS Deals with Files
resources.description: This course from IPFS Camp 2019 offers a deep exploration of how IPFS deals with files, including key concepts like immutability, content addressing, hashing, the anatomy of CIDs, what the heck a Merkle DAG is, and how chunk size affects file imports.

resources.title: The Lifecycle of Data in the DWeb
resources.description: Curious about what happens _after_ you've added data to IPFS? This IPFS Camp 2019 course explores how peers discover and share files on the network, from providing to getting to pinning to deleting.

resources.title: IPFS: Regular Files API
resources.description: Ready to deal with more than primitives? Explore the API custom-built for efficient handling of files in IPFS.

0004.title: Mutable File System
0004.description: The Mutable File System (MFS) lets you work with files and directories as if you were using a traditional name-based file system.
0004.updateMessage: Version `0.48` of `js-ipfs` has introduced some changes, most notably by changing the acceptable formats for moving multiple files with `ipfs.files.mv`. This means that **some code challenge solutions have changed**. We recommend re-visiting this tutorial to learn about the updated methods and complete the revised challenges!

resources.title: JS-IPFS Files API
resources.description: Notice that these docs contain two sections, one for top-level methods relevant to files and one for the Mutable File System (MFS) you learned about in this tutorial.

resources.title: Understanding How IPFS Deals with Files
resources.description: This course from IPFS Camp 2019 offers a deep exploration of how IPFS deals with files, including key concepts like immutability, content addressing, hashing, the anatomy of CIDs, what the heck a Merkle DAG is, and how chunk size affects file imports. It also introduces some the joys and pitfalls of the Mutable File System (MFS).

resources.title: The Lifecycle of Data in the DWeb
resources.description: Curious about what happens _after_ you've added files to IPFS? This course from IPFS Camp 2019 explores how peers discover and share files on the network, from providing to getting to pinning to deleting.

resources.title: IPFS: Regular Files API
resources.description: Explore the other half of the IPFS Files API, where you'll add and retrieve files and read their contents without the abstraction layer of the Mutable File System.

resources.title: Browser MFS Demo
resources.description: Try out MFS methods in your broswer and watch your file directory change as you go.

resources.title: Jeromy Coffee Talks: Files API
resources.description: Wondering how the Mutable File System (MFS) can treat immutable data as though it's mutable? Jeromy Johnson of Protocol Labs explains the abstraction that makes it possible.

resources.title: P2P Data Links with Content Addressing
resources.description: You've seen the IPFS Files API. Now explore the IPFS DAG API, where you'll use CIDs to create verifiable links between datasets.

0005.title: Regular Files API
0005.description: The IPFS Regular Files API provides a way to store and share files in a peer-to-peer storage system.
0005.updateMessage: Version `0.48` of `js-ipfs` has introduced some changes, most notably by adding `addAll` to use with multiple files, while `add` can now only be used with a single file. This means that **some code challenge solutions have changed**. We recommend re-visiting this tutorial to learn about the updated methods and complete the revised challenges!

resources.title: JS-IPFS Files API
resources.description: Notice that these docs contain two sections, one for top-level methods relevant to files, which we learned about in this tutorial, and one for the Mutable File System (MFS).

resources.title: Understanding How IPFS Deals with Files
resources.description: This course from IPFS Camp 2019 offers a deep exploration of how IPFS deals with files, including key concepts like immutability, content addressing, hashing, the anatomy of CIDs, what the heck a Merkle DAG is, and how chunk size affects file imports. It also introduces some the joys and pitfalls of the Mutable File System (MFS).

resources.title: The Lifecycle of Data in the DWeb
resources.description: Curious about what happens _after_ you've added files to IPFS? This course from IPFS Camp 2019 explores how peers discover and share files on the network, from providing to getting to pinning to deleting.

resources.title: IPFS: Mutable File System (MFS)
resources.description: Wish adding files to IPFS felt more like using a traditional name-based file system? Explore the Mutable File System (MFS).

resources.title: P2P Data Links with Content Addressing
resources.description: You've seen the IPFS Files API. Now explore the IPFS DAG API, where you'll use CIDs to create verifiable links between datasets.

0006.title: Anatomy of a CID
0006.description: Explore the ins and outs of CIDs (Content Identifiers), the unique labels used to point to data stored on distributed information systems including IPFS, IPLD, libp2p, and Filecoin.

resources.title: How IPFS Deals With Files: Anatomy of a CID
resources.description: Watch the talk that inspired this tutorial! In Part 2 of this core course from IPFS Camp 2019, Alan Shaw explains the anatomy of a CID.

resources.title: CID Inspector
resources.description: Paste a CID into this handy web app for a human-readable breakdown of its multibase, multicodec, multihash and version.

resources.title: Hashes
resources.description: Learn more about cryptographic hashes in the official IPFS docs.

resources.title: Multiformats
resources.description: Explore Multiformats, a collection of protocols that future-proof systems, including CID, multihash, multibase and multicodec.

resources.title: Multihash
resources.description: Learn more about the multihash protocol for differentiating outputs from various well-established hash functions, addressing size and encoding considerations.

resources.title: Content Identifier (CID) Specification
resources.description: Review the specification for CID, the self-describing content-addressed identifier for distributed systems like IPFS and IPLD.

0007.title: Verifying Storage on Filecoin
0007.description: Learn how Filecoin's built-in verification methods make it possible to trust peers in an incentivized, decentralized file storage system.
0007.newMessage: Interested in Filecoin but want to know more about its core concepts? Our first-ever Filecoin tutorial explains how the protocol uses proofs and consensus mechanisms to incentivize good behavior on the part of storage providers.

resources.title: What Sets Us Apart: Filecoinâ€™s Proof System
resources.description: Explore what sets Filecoin apart from other blockchains in this blog post from founder Juan Benet.

resources.title: Scaling Proof of Replication for Filecoin Mining
resources.description: Learn more about the powers of Proof of Replication (PoRep) in this academic paper from Ben Fisch, Joseph Bonneau, Nicola Greco, and Juan Benet.

resources.title: Good SNARKs are Here Needed
resources.description: Explore ZK SNARKs in this Zcon0 talk from Nicola Greco of Protocol Labs.

resources.title: Filecoin Spec
resources.description: Take a deep dive into the technical side of Filecoin in the spec for the protocol.

resources.title: Anatomy of a CID
resources.description: Explore how CIDs are constructed in Filecoin, from multihash and multicodec prefixes to CID versions. (No coding required.)

resources.title: Merkle DAGs: Structuring Data for the Distributed Web
resources.description: Learn about the benefits of Merkle DAGs, unique content-addressed data structures for the distributed networks like Filecoin. (No coding required.)

0008.title: Merkle DAGs: Structuring Data for the Distributed Web
0008.description: Learn how we can use CIDs to create content-addressable data structures for the distributed web!

resources.title: Understanding How IPFS Deals with Files
resources.description: This course from IPFS Camp 2019 offers a deep exploration of how IPFS deals with files, including key concepts like immutability, content addressing, hashing, the anatomy of CIDs, what the heck a Merkle DAG is, and how chunk size affects file imports.

resources.title: P2P Data Links with Content Addressing
resources.description: Ready to get hands on with Merkle DAGs? In this JavaScript coding tutorial, youâ€™ll use the IPFS DAG API to add data objects to IPFS and link between them.

resources.title: Blogging on the Decentralized Web
resources.description: In this hands-on JavaScript tutorial, use the IPFS DAG API to encode relationships between authors, posts, and tags as you create a blog.

resources.title: Thinking in Data Structures
resources.description: In this tutorial from IPLD, practice using data structures to describe data.

resources.title: Content-Addressed Distributed Data Structures
resources.description: In this talk from the SpeakeasyJS meetup, Rod Vagg covers the basics of content-addressing, Merkle DAGs, and IPLD.

resources.title: How Merkle Trees Enable the Decentralized Web
resources.description: In this talk from !!Con 2017, Tara Vancil explains the unique properties that make Merkle trees the backbone of decentralized software like Git,BitTorrent, ZFS, and Ethereum.

resources.title: InterPlanetary Linked Data (IPLD)
resources.description: Explore the IPLD project, an ecosystem of formats and data structures for building fully decentralized applications.

0009.title: Introduction to libp2p
0009.description: Learn how libp2p solves common networking problems through modularity, aiming to be the de facto peer-to-peer (P2P) library for the decentralized web.

resources.title: libp2p Website
resources.description: Explore libp2p's native implementations, videos of conference talks, specifications, and documentation.

resources.title: libp2p Documentation
resources.description: Dig deeper into libp2p's concepts and modules on its docs site, which includes a glossary and code examples across Go, JavaScript, and Rust implementations.

resources.title: Introduction to libp2p
resources.description: Watch the talk from David Dias that heavily inspired this tutorial, in which he explains we need libp2p, how it works, and what its future objectives are.

resources.title: js-libp2p Code Examples
resources.description: Explore libp2p code examples in JavaScript, indluding a chat app, browser, encrypted communications, peer and content routing, and more.

resources.title: Getting started with js-libp2p
resources.description: Walk through the process of setting up a fully functional js-libp2p node using JavaScript. ðŸš€

resources.title: js-libp2p Configuration
resources.description: Learn how to configure js-libp2p for your particular project.

resources.title: go-libp2p Code Examples
resources.description: Explore libp2p code examples in the Go programming language, including a chat app, a basic getting started echo client and server example, and more.

resources.title: Content Addressing on the Decentralized Web
resources.description: Many of the applications that incorporate libp2p for _process addressing_ also use _content addressing_ to identify the data shared among peers on a decentralized network. Learn more about content addressing in our most popular ProtoSchool tutorial.
